payload.instructions:
# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- Main code lives in `spec-kit/src/specify_cli/__init__.py`; CLI entrypoint is `specify`.
- Templates that drive generated projects are in `spec-kit/templates/` (commands, tasks, prompts, etc.).
- Helper scripts for contributors are in `spec-kit/scripts/` (bash and PowerShell variants); docs and guides sit in `spec-kit/docs/`.
- Governance memory (e.g., `spec-kit/memory/constitution.md`) guides agents; update when process changes.
- Media/assets live in `spec-kit/media/`; published changelog and policies sit alongside (`CHANGELOG.md`, `CONTRIBUTING.md`, `SECURITY.md`).

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- First-time setup: `cd spec-kit && uv sync` (Python 3.11+ required).
- Fast local run without install: `cd spec-kit && python -m src.specify_cli --help` or `python -m src.specify_cli init demo --ai copilot --ignore-agent-tools --script sh`.
- Editable install: `cd spec-kit && uv pip install -e .` then `specify ...` is available on PATH.
- Simulate end-user flow from the current branch: `cd spec-kit && uvx --from . specify init demo-uvx --ai claude --ignore-agent-tools`.
- Package check: `cd spec-kit && uv build` (outputs to `dist/`).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- Python code uses 4-space indent, type hints, and Typer commands with rich output; follow existing command patterns and helper utilities in `specify_cli`.
- Keep option/flag names kebab-case for the CLI and snake_case in Python; prefer small, composable functions over new globals.
- Templates are prefixed with `speckit.` and scripts use hyphenated names (e.g., `create-new-feature.sh`); match these patterns when adding files.
- Linting is light; keep imports tidy and run `python -c "import specify_cli"` for a quick sanity check.

## Testing Guidelines
- There is no automated test suite today; run smoke flows after changes:
  - `python -m src.specify_cli init demo --ai copilot --ignore-agent-tools` in a temp directory.
  - Verify generated scripts are executable (`ls -l scripts/*.sh`) and Windows-friendly (`.ps1` present).
- Adjust `templates/` and docs when behavior changes; manual validation is expected before PRs.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Discuss large template/CLI changes with maintainers before opening a PR. Work on feature branches (`git checkout -b feature-name`).
- Commit messages should be clear and scoped; update `CHANGELOG.md` when altering user-facing behavior.
- PRs should describe intent, testing performed, and impacted templates/scripts; link related issues and screenshots/logs when relevant.
- Document any AI assistance in the PR (per `CONTRIBUTING.md`), ensure docs (`README.md`, `spec-driven.md`, `docs/*.md`) stay in sync, and avoid committing secrets (tokens like `GH_TOKEN` are for local use only).

content.text:
# AGENTS.md instructions for /home/todd/Dev/gm-kit

<INSTRUCTIONS>
# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- Main code lives in `spec-kit/src/specify_cli/__init__.py`; CLI entrypoint is `specify`.
- Templates that drive generated projects are in `spec-kit/templates/` (commands, tasks, prompts, etc.).
- Helper scripts for contributors are in `spec-kit/scripts/` (bash and PowerShell variants); docs and guides sit in `spec-kit/docs/`.
- Governance memory (e.g., `spec-kit/memory/constitution.md`) guides agents; update when process changes.
- Media/assets live in `spec-kit/media/`; published changelog and policies sit alongside (`CHANGELOG.md`, `CONTRIBUTING.md`, `SECURITY.md`).

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- First-time setup: `cd spec-kit && uv sync` (Python 3.11+ required).
- Fast local run without install: `cd spec-kit && python -m src.specify_cli --help` or `python -m src.specify_cli init demo --ai copilot --ignore-agent-tools --script sh`.
- Editable install: `cd spec-kit && uv pip install -e .` then `specify ...` is available on PATH.
- Simulate end-user flow from the current branch: `cd spec-kit && uvx --from . specify init demo-uvx --ai claude --ignore-agent-tools`.
- Package check: `cd spec-kit && uv build` (outputs to `dist/`).

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- Python code uses 4-space indent, type hints, and Typer commands with rich output; follow existing command patterns and helper utilities in `specify_cli`.
- Keep option/flag names kebab-case for the CLI and snake_case in Python; prefer small, composable functions over new globals.
- Templates are prefixed with `speckit.` and scripts use hyphenated names (e.g., `create-new-feature.sh`); match these patterns when adding files.
- Linting is light; keep imports tidy and run `python -c "import specify_cli"` for a quick sanity check.

## Testing Guidelines
- There is no automated test suite today; run smoke flows after changes:
  - `python -m src.specify_cli init demo --ai copilot --ignore-agent-tools` in a temp directory.
  - Verify generated scripts are executable (`ls -l scripts/*.sh`) and Windows-friendly (`.ps1` present).
- Adjust `templates/` and docs when behavior changes; manual validation is expected before PRs.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Discuss large template/CLI changes with maintainers before opening a PR. Work on feature branches (`git checkout -b feature-name`).
- Commit messages should be clear and scoped; update `CHANGELOG.md` when altering user-facing behavior.
- PRs should describe intent, testing performed, and impacted templates/scripts; link related issues and screenshots/logs when relevant.
- Document any AI assistance in the PR (per `CONTRIBUTING.md`), ensure docs (`README.md`, `spec-driven.md`, `docs/*.md`) stay in sync, and avoid committing secrets (tokens like `GH_TOKEN` are for local use only).

</INSTRUCTIONS>

[build-system]
requires = ["setuptools", "wheel"]
build-backend = "setuptools.build_meta"

[project]
name = "surgebench"
version = "0.1.0"
description = "Convert Surge XT FXP presets to modular bench patches"
authors = [{name = "Your Name"}]
dependencies = [
    "typer",
    "toml",
    "zstd",
    "requests",
    "json5",
    "rich",
]
requires-python = ">=3.10"

[project.optional-dependencies]
dev = [
    "pytest",
    "black",
    "isort",
    "ruff",
    "mypy",
]

[project.scripts]
surgebench = "surgebench.cli:app"
modulemap = "modulemap.cli:app"
mapmodule = "modulemap.cli:app"

[tool.pytest.ini_options]
testpaths = ["tests"]
python_files = "test_*.py"
python_classes = "Test*"
python_functions = "test_*"
pythonpath = ["src"]

[tool.black]
line-length = 88
target-version = ['py311']
include = '\.pyi?$'
extend-exclude = '''
/(
  # directories
  \.eggs
  | \.git
  | \.hg
  | \.mypy_cache
  | \.tox
  | \.venv
  | build
  | dist
)/
'''

[tool.isort]
profile = "black"
multi_line_output = 3
line_length = 88

[tool.mypy]
python_version = "3.11"
warn_return_any = true
warn_unused_configs = true
disallow_untyped_defs = true
disallow_incomplete_defs = true
check_untyped_defs = true
disallow_untyped_decorators = true
no_implicit_optional = true
warn_redundant_casts = true
warn_unused_ignores = true
warn_no_return = true
warn_unreachable = true
strict_equality = true

[tool.ruff]
line-length = 88
target-version = "py311"

[tool.ruff.lint]
select = [
    "E",  # pycodestyle errors
    "W",  # pycodestyle warnings
    "F",  # pyflakes
    "I",  # isort
    "B",  # flake8-bugbear
    "C4", # flake8-comprehensions
    "UP", # pyupgrade
]
ignore = [
    # Allow non-abstract empty methods in abstract base classes
    "B027",
    # Allow boolean positional values in function calls, like `dict.get(... True)`
    "FBT003",
    # Ignore checks for possible passwords
    "S105", "S106", "S107",
    # Ignore complexity
    "C901", "PLR0911", "PLR0912", "PLR0913", "PLR0915",
]

[tool.ruff.lint.mccabe]
max-complexity = 10

# Some todos

1. Add the knowledge-graph mcp and see if it improves on the adhoc implementations from opencode/gemini/codex/copilot.  A universal session distiller is more preferred than trying to blend/use the ones provided by each different vendor.

2. One thing I'm learning is that the original pdf AND the converted markdown are just a starting point.  They should not be relevant to the final document at all.  The final document is what the GM will use at the table and any of the old documenation is just noise.  So the final document should have everything the GM needs to run the game.  There should be no need to refer back to the original (so maybe hyperlinks back to the the original, but remove them when during the final step).

On that note, we need to encourage the player to establish their preferences for each final artifact as context is critical.  Discuss this with AI as you develop GM Kit so that these artifacts are customizable by the GM AS CONTEXT. Just like with spec-kit, none of the prompts or templates, etc are set in stone.  Some GM's want read aloud text, others want a few quick tags, others want specific fields (looks like, sounds like, etc).  

From my findings, I think this TOP-DOWN order of steps is the best approach:

- Convert pdf to markdown.
    - For testing:
        - Use the ubiquitous dmsguild format as an initial test.
        - Test against call of cthulhu, etc. 
    - Th AI will analyze the pdf and make a recommendation of two possible approaches for the conversion: 
    - Give them two approaches:
        - AI performs the conversion (more exact -- I think) and less errors, but eats a lot of context and usage.
        - AI analyzes the PDF and then creates a command line for a CLI conversion utility to perform the conversion, then cleans up the output mardown as needed.
    - The user will select an approach
    - The AI will execute the approach and using a checklist will vett the output afterwards.
    - Additionally, (and if possible) the AI will use command line tools to extract all of the images from the pdf and put them in a doc-images folder.
- User will double check the order and hiearchy of the titles and sections.
    - He should read the background info, and any plot synopsis to get a sense of things.
- AI will generate a multiple resources:
    - Any errata specific included in scenario but distilled down to an outline, this can be 
        - Advice on running the game, 
        - GM Notes
        - As with the other story elements below, the AI can prompt the user to ensure tone, etc. This will allow the user to change the tone, provide reference points (film, books, other games, etc).  This allows the AI to use this information as context for the story elements. 
        - NOTE: This does NOT include character sheets, maps, etc.  just the general overview details for the GM.
    - A summary of events, characters and monsters and cuasation routes. Each item should have it's own ID so it's easy t reference (maybe a 3 character or digit tag like AGG or 222, or similar? Or just the outline element, so I.A.2.d?  Seems two involved).  I'll need to think about this.
        - NOTE some of these routes may be inferred if not explicit but should be tagged as so.
        - NOT: This outline can be as text, and/or a visigraph/mermaid/DOT diagram.
        - User reviews, discusses, changes and vetts the diagram by asking questions and making recommendations.
        - Examples of elements to review, change, etc:
            - The plot hook (the inciting incident) that pulls the PCs into the game.
            - The background information, including the setting (time and place), the locations, the scenes, the NPCs/monsters the plot route.  This allows the GM to slot the scenario into an ongoing campaign.
            - Once these changes are in place, it's a good time to feed the character sheets for the PCs to the agent so it can analyze opportunities for the players to complete goals, show off special skills or resources, etc.  It can also make recommendations for changes to ensure these integrations are fixed.  This should embed all challenge rolls (either from the original scenario) 
            - He can also have the AI analyze the the plot route to look for holes, logic gaps or other inconsistencies that make the route brittle, following the 3-clue rule, etc. 
        - AI modifies the summary and vetts the modifications IN THE OUTLINE and diagrams.  It then creates a "plot restructure plan and checklist" for making the revisions.
        - For the diagram and outline, each scene or encounter is marked with the type:  exploration, social, combat (or a combination).

- At this point the errata should have established tone and themes. This is important as we expand the scenario.

- User drills down into specifics and expands the text outline:
    - Verify the rule system, if they want to convert to another system, they'll need to provide both rule sets. 
        - The AI will analyze both the input rule system and the output rule system and then create the plan to translate and execute it.   It will then verify the changes. 
        - Here is what it will change
            - PC/NPC/Monster stats.
            - Challenge/Skill/Save rolls.
    - User and AI review the scenes or encounters together and determine which ones need expansion and refinement.
        - Examples of revisions/expansions:
            - Combat: 
                - Room layout, props/platforms/barrierrs to use in battle, dynamic combat goals, escalating events, etc.
                - Ensuring balanced comabat scenarios and exit ramps for both the PCs and the BBG.
            - Exploration:
                - Follow the 
        - AI makes a plan and executes it.  It will modify existing outlines and diagrams, and insert a new scene/encounter fully fleshed out following the templates as provided by gm-kit and modified by the user. You don't have to do this for every scene or location.  Just the ones you really want to have ready.
    
    ANOTHER IDEA: 

    Convert a dungeon module into markdown outline with each room as it's own page, with hyperlinks on the map to the specific page.  Each room has bullet points with room descriptions, reduced npc/monster stat blocks, quick room descriptions, areas of exploration, events etc.  See if obsidian already has some kind of plugin and format for this.

[project]
name = "specify-cli"
version = "0.0.22"
description = "Specify CLI, part of GitHub Spec Kit. A tool to bootstrap your projects for Spec-Driven Development (SDD)."
requires-python = ">=3.11"
dependencies = [
    "typer",
    "rich",
    "httpx[socks]",
    "platformdirs",
    "readchar",
    "truststore>=0.10.4",
]

[project.scripts]
specify = "specify_cli:main"

[build-system]
requires = ["hatchling"]
build-backend = "hatchling.build"

[tool.hatch.build.targets.wheel]
packages = ["src/specify_cli"]

payload.name: apply_patch

payload.text:
**Preparing final message about pyproject changes**

I'm putting together a clear message explaining the reset of the packaging metadata in pyproject.toml with line references, mentioning that tests haven't been run yet, and suggesting next steps like customizing authors and running initialization commands. I'll make it concise and easy to follow with bullet points.

payload.message:
**Pyproject Reset**
- Switched to a clean Hatchling-based build setup and removed the old project-specific metadata so this repo now has a neutral package scaffold (`pyproject.toml:1-3`).
- Added fresh project metadata for `gm-kit`, empty dependency lists, and a lightweight dev extra to keep the new environment blank but ready for tooling (`pyproject.toml:5-19`).
- Trimmed the tool config down to just basic pytest, Black, and Ruff defaults so future settings can be added as the project takes shape (`pyproject.toml:21-32`).

No tests were run (nothing to execute yet).

Next steps: 1) update the placeholder author/info fields, 2) create your `src/` and `tests/` directories, then 3) run `uv sync` or `pip install -e .[dev]` once you start adding code.

content.text:
**Pyproject Reset**
- Switched to a clean Hatchling-based build setup and removed the old project-specific metadata so this repo now has a neutral package scaffold (`pyproject.toml:1-3`).
- Added fresh project metadata for `gm-kit`, empty dependency lists, and a lightweight dev extra to keep the new environment blank but ready for tooling (`pyproject.toml:5-19`).
- Trimmed the tool config down to just basic pytest, Black, and Ruff defaults so future settings can be added as the project takes shape (`pyproject.toml:21-32`).

No tests were run (nothing to execute yet).

Next steps: 1) update the placeholder author/info fields, 2) create your `src/` and `tests/` directories, then 3) run `uv sync` or `pip install -e .[dev]` once you start adding code.
